archimate:BusinessObject.name: AI Act
archimate:BusinessObject.documentation:
Short about purpose and target group
The Al Regulation targets all providers, manufacturers, distributors (and to some extent users) of Al systems (information systems that use Al algorithms). The purpose of the proposal for a regulation is to harmonize rules for Al within the EU and to: 1. ensure that Al systems deployed and used in the internal market are secure and are developed and used in accordance with fundamental rights, in accordance with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and Union values; 2. ensure legal certainty and predictability to facilitate investment and innovation in Al, 3. improve governance and effective enforcement of existing laws on fundamental rights and security requirements applicable to Al and 4. facilitate the development of a single market for legal, safe and reliable Al systems and prevent fragmentation.
The most important commitments for Sweden
Prohibition of certain forms of "high-risk Al", extensive requirements on relevant actors, in particular if they provide, produce, distribute or use high-risk Al systems (including extensive requirements on risk management, "data governance", documentation, transparency, human transparency, information and cyber security (all-risk), quality control systems, ecosystem of certification organizations ("notified bodies"), standardization, CE marking, introduction of "regulatory sandboxes" (environments where Al systems can be developed in a safe manner, and where not having to comply with regulation - a mechanism to support innovation and test ideas before deciding on a venture that can be very expensive), strong oversight (deep access to sensitive data (including source code), high penalties (in some cases the highest of EUR 30,000,000 million or 6 % of global turnover), closure of service, dismissal of persons in a managerial position).
The most important opportunities for Sweden, including the impact on security
Al has long been used by many companies and in the public sector. Development is fast. At the same time, Al technology means that systems can be trained to perform a task while it is being performed. Over time, this may mean that the Al system begins to act in unforeseen or unauthorized ways. The Al regulation provides legal opportunities to collectively manage the risks that Al systems entail and may entail, especially when they are used to provide socially important services, in the activities of authorities or in other respects. The core of the Al regulation is therefore about ensuring that Al systems maintain a high level of accuracy (that they do what they are meant to do, that they do nothing other than what they are meant to do and that we can trust that this is the case) over their entire life cycle, as well as enabling society to intervene if that level of accuracy is not maintained.
The regulation will clarify an area that is currently characterized by a lot of uncertainty regarding development and use. This is deemed to contribute positively to safe products and consequently safety in a wider perspective.
Time perspective (when it starts to apply)
The regulation may be adopted in 2023 and will come into effect two years later.
